Utilities¶

Contents¶

pyavia.core.util.kind_div

Tries integer division of x/y before resorting to float.

pyavia.core.util.force_type

Try converting x into a series of types, with no check on the conversion validity.

pyavia.core.util.coax_type

Try converting x into a series of types, returning first result where next_type(x) == x.

Shorthand function for all(x is None for x in args).

pyavia.core.util.all_not_none

Shorthand function for all(x is not None for x in args).

Shorthand function for any(x is None for x in args).

Interpolate data points to find remaining unknown values absent from p with optionally scaled axes.

Shorthand for monotonic(iterable, +1, strict=True, key=key).

Members¶

Useful small, general purpose utilities not offered in the standard library, such as:

  • Extended operators for generic types (e.g. kind_div, force_type, coax_type).

  • Shorthand functions for commonly used tasks (e.g. all_none, all_not_none).

  • Functions for searching, interpolating and extrapolating sequences (e.g. bracket_list, linear_int_ext, monotonic).

pyavia.core.util.all_none(*args)¶

Shorthand function for all(x is None for x in args). Returns True if all *args are None, otherwise False.

pyavia.core.util.all_not_none(*args)¶

Shorthand function for all(x is not None for x in args). Returns True if all *args are not None, otherwise False.

pyavia.core.util.any_none(*args)¶

Shorthand function for any(x is None for x in args). Returns True if any of *args are None, otherwise False.

pyavia.core.util.bounded_by(x, iterable, key=None)¶

Returns True if x is bounded by the given iterable. I.E. min(iterable) <= x <= max(iterable). If key function is provided this is applied to x and the iterable values before comparison.

pyavia.core.util.bracket_list(li, x, key=None)¶

Returns left and right indicies (l_idx, r_idx) of a sorted list that bracket x. I.E. where li`[`l_idx] <= x <= li`[`r_idx].

Note

This is not the same as the usual one-sided methods which ensure strict inequality on one side (e.g. low <= x < high). This means that for boundary values two brackets may satisfy the condition.

Parameters

  • li – Sorted list / tuple. Sorting can be in either direction.

  • x – Value to bracket.

  • key – Comparison function if supplied. Default = None.

Returns

(l_idx, r_idx). Note that r_idx = l_idx + 1 on return. For x equal to a middle list value, the left side bracket is returned.

pyavia.core.util.coax_type(x, *types, default=None)¶

Try converting x into a series of types, returning first result where next_type(x) == x.

Examples

>>> pa.coax_type(3.5, int, float)  # float result.
3.5
>>> pa.coax_type(3.0, int, str)  # int result.
3
>>> pa.coax_type ("3.0", int, float)  # Error: 3.0 != "3.0".
Traceback (most recent call last):
...
ValueError: Couldn't coax '3.0' to <class 'int'> or <class 'float'>.
>>> x = 3 + 2j
>>> pa.coax_type(x, int, float, default=x)  # Can't convert, gives default.
(3+2j)
Parameters

  • x – Argument to be converted.

  • types (list_like) – Target types to use when trying conversion.

  • default – Value to return if conversion was unsuccessful.

Returns

x converted to the first successful type (if possible) or default.

Raises

ValueError – If default is None and conversion was unsuccessful.

pyavia.core.util.count_op(it: Iterable, oper, value)¶

Return a count of the number of items in it where oper value == True. This allows user-defined objects to be included and is subtly different to [...].count(...) which uses the __eq__ operator.

pyavia.core.util.first(it: Iterable, condition=<function <lambda>>)¶

Function returning the first item in the iterable that satisfies the condition. This function is taken almost directly from: https://stackoverflow.com/a/35513376

>>> pa.first((1,2,3), condition=lambda x: x % 2 == 0)
2
>>> pa.first(range(3, 100))
3
>>> pa.first(())
Traceback (most recent call last):
...
StopIteration
Parameters

  • it – Iterable to search.

  • condition – (Opt) Boolean condition applied to each iterable. If the condition is not given, the first item is returned.

Returns

First item in the iterable ‘it’ that satisfying the condition.

Raises

StopIteration if no item satysfing the condition is found. –

pyavia.core.util.force_type(x, *types)¶

Try converting x into a series of types, with no check on the conversion validity.

Examples

>>> pa.force_type(3.5, int, float)
... # Results in an int, because int(x) accepts float and truncates.
3
>>> pa.force_type("3.5+4j", float, complex)
(3.5+4j)
>>> pa.force_type(3.5+4j, int, float, str)
'(3.5+4j)'
Parameters

  • x – Argument to be converted.

  • types (list_like) – Target types to use when trying conversion.

Returns

x converted to the first successful type, if possible.

Raises

ValueError – If no conversion was possible.

pyavia.core.util.kind_atan2(y, x) → float¶

Implementation of atan2 that allows any object as an argument provided it supports __div__ and __float__. Allows units-aware usage.

pyavia.core.util.kind_div(x, y) → Union[int, float]¶

Tries integer division of x/y before resorting to float. If integer division gives no remainder, returns this result otherwise it returns the float result. From https://stackoverflow.com/a/36637240.

pyavia.core.util.line_pt(a, b, p, scale=None)¶

Find the coordinates of a point p anywhere along the line a → b where at least one component of p is supplied (remaining can be None). Each axis may be optionally scaled. There is no limitation that p is in the interval [a, b], so this function can also be used for extrapolation as required.

Parameters

  • a (list_like) – Two distinct points on a line i.e. \([x_1, ..., x_n]\)

  • b (list_like) – Two distinct points on a line i.e. \([x_1, ..., x_n]\)

  • p (list_like) – Required point on the line with at least a single known component, i.e. \((..., None, p_i, None, ...)\). If more than one value is supplied, the first is used.

  • scale (list) –

    If supplied, a list corresponding to each axis [opt_1, …, opt_n], where each axis can use the following options:

    • None: No scaling performed.

    • ’log’: This axis is linear on a log scale. In practice

      log(x) is performed on this axis prior to doing the interpolation / extrapolation, then exp(x) is done prior to returning.

Returns

Required point on line \([q_1, ..., q_n]\) where \(q_i = p_i\) from above.

Return type

list

pyavia.core.util.linear_int_ext(data_pts, p, scale=None, allow_extrap=False)¶

Interpolate data points to find remaining unknown values absent from p with optionally scaled axes. If p is not in the range and allow_extra == True, a linear extrapolation is done using the two data points at the end corresponding to the p.

Parameters

  • data_pts (list_like(tuple)) – [(a_1, … a_n), …] sorted on the required axis (either direction).

  • p (list_like) – Required point to interpolate / extrapolate with at least a single known component, i.e. \((..., None, p_i, None, ...)\). If more than one is supplied, the first is used.

  • scale – Same as line_pt scale.

  • allow_extrap (bool, optional) – If True linear extrapolation from the two adjacent endpoints is permitted. Default = False.

Returns

Interpolated / extrapolated point \([q_1, ..., q_n]\) where \(q_i = p_i\) from above.

Return type

list

pyavia.core.util.min_max(iterable, key=None)¶

Returns (min, max) of elements in iterable. Comparison provided using key if supplied.

pyavia.core.util.monotonic(iterable, dirn, strict=True, key=None)¶

Returns True if elements of iterable are monotonic otherwise false. For dirn >= 0 the sequence is strictly increasing i.e. \(x_{i+1} > x_i\), otherwise it is strictly decreasing i.e. \(x_i+1 < x_i\). If strict = False then equality is sufficient (i.e. >=, <= instead of >, <). Comparison provided using key if supplied.

pyavia.core.util.strict_decrease(iterable, key=None)¶

Shorthand for monotonic(iterable, -1, strict=True, key=key). Returns True i.f.f. all \(x_{i+1} < x_i\). Comparison provided using key if supplied.

pyavia.core.util.strict_increase(iterable, key=None)¶

Shorthand for monotonic(iterable, +1, strict=True, key=key). Returns True i.f.f. all \(x_{i+1} > x_i\). Comparison provided using key if supplied.
